poem:
### Harehills Inferno

In Harehills' shadowed lanes, fierce fires leap,
whispers twist, four flames in predawn sleep.
A rumour spreads, spills on parched street,
lawlessness blooms where shadows meet.
Men jailed, judged, their anger stark,
in the court's echo, the city's dark.
A blaze of fury, unchecked, unplanned—
dystopia's touch on trembling land.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Four men jailed for arson and violent disorder in Harehills riot Four men have been jailed for taking part in “dystopian” mob violence that engulfed a Leeds suburb after rumours spread about the treatment of four children who were taken into care. A judge said the disorder in Harehills on 18 July was “a chilling example of how a violent, anarchic mob can, with astonishing ease, achieve a situation of complete lawlessness”. Leeds crown court". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
